heading.title: PART 20 RESOLUTION OF PROCEEDINGS WITHOUT HEARING [rr 20.1–20.34]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 20 RESOLUTION OF PROCEEDINGS WITHOUT HEARING [rr 20.1–20.34]

p.text: In this Division:
means an order in force under rule 20.14 .
includes any question or issue arising in any proceedings, whether of fact or law, or both, and whether raised by pleadings, agreement of parties or otherwise.
Legislation cited in [20.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.24.

Under this Division the court has a general discretion, except in matters to be tried by jury, to appoint referees and refer to them either the whole of the proceedings or any questions to which they give rise. Referees appointed under this Division are not officers of the court and their reports have no legal consequence unless or until they are adopted by the court: Xeureb v Viola (1989) 18 NSWLR 453 at 465–6 and r 20.24 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.14] r 20.14 Orders of referral (cf SCR Part 72, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Orders of referral (cf SCR Part 72, rule 2)

p.text: At any stage of the proceedings, the court may make orders for reference to a referee appointed by the court for inquiry and report by the referee on the whole of the proceedings or on any question arising in the proceedings.
The court must not make an order under subrule (1) in respect of a question to be tried with a jury.
Legislation cited in [20.14.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 6.42–6.44.

The present rule confers a general discretion to refer matters to a referee whenever the court is satisfied that doing so will best achieve the overriding purpose of the Rules — the just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings. The discretion to refer is thus stated in general terms and requires proper regard to be paid to the nature of the issues in dispute, the appropriateness of resolving them by ordinary trial procedures, any potential saving of time and expense as a result of making an order for reference out and the general desirability of making such an order in the particular circumstances. An order for reference may be made at any time, including after the commencement of the hearing: Stockland (Constructors) Pty Ltd v Darryl I Coombs Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 333; BC200402167 .

Typically, disputes that involve significant technical issues are suitable for reference out — because of the expectation that an appropriately selected referee will provide the most efficient, economical and accurate determination of issues of that kind. The rules specifically contemplate that the Supreme Court may make an order referring disputed issues of foreign law: see UCPR rr 6.42–6.44 .

An order for reference out may be made, as the rule implicitly contemplates, irrespective of the preferences of the parties: Park Rail Developments Pty Ltd v R J Pearce Assocs Pty Ltd (1987) 8 NSWLR 123 ; and, notwithstanding some authorities to the contrary: Taylor & Sons Pty Ltd v Brival Pty Ltd [1982] VR 762 ; Honeywell Pty Ltd v Austral Motors Holdings Ltd [1980] Qd R 355 ; Everingham v Clarke [1994] 1 Qd R 34; BC9202603 . Where parties disagree on the appointment of a referee the court may invite a professional body to nominate suitably qualified people who are willing to accept appointment: see Ahmed v Chowdhury (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 954; BC201106419 .

A question or issue referred will usually be specifically stated, but the court may make an order referring all questions or issues in the proceedings that have not already been decided. At least in circumstances where the referee is an experienced lawyer, it is desirable to include in the order specific powers to permit amendment of the pleadings and the issues to be determined in the reference: AMP Fire and General Insurance Co Ltd v Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney and Clarke JJA, No 40346/93, 14 July 1993, unreported, BC9301811). In this context, see the usual form of order for reference in Supreme Court Practice Note SC Eq 3, Annexure 2.

level.toc-caption: [20.14.15] Foreign law — referral under UCPR r 20.14

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.14.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Div 9, r 20.14.

heading.title: Foreign law — referral under UCPR r 20.14

p.text: There are specific provisions relating to the commencement of proceedings involving disputed questions of foreign law: see of UCPR Pt 6 Div 9 . Under those provisions disputed issues of foreign law may be the subject of an order by the Supreme Court for reference under UCPR r 20.14 : see also Fleming v Marshall (2011) 279 ALR 737; [2011] NSWCA 86; BC201101958 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.15] r 20.15 Appointment of referees (cf SCR Part 72, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Appointment of referees (cf SCR Part 72, rule 3)

p.text: Subject to this rule, the court may appoint any person as a referee.
A judicial officer or other officer of the court may not act as a referee otherwise than with the concurrence of the senior judicial officer.

An arbitrator nominated by the parties in respect of some issues in dispute between them may also be appointed by the court as a referee. The appointment may be particularly appropriate where the arbitrator has special competence or where the matters in issue in the arbitration and in the prospective reference are common or similar: Aerospatiale Holdings Australia Pty Ltd v Elspan International Ltd (1992) 28 NSWLR 321 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.16] r 20.16 Two or more referees (cf SCR Part 72, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Two or more referees (cf SCR Part 72, rule 4)

p.text: If the court appoints 2 referees and a decision to be made in the course of proceedings under the reference is not agreed, the decision that is binding is:
if a judicial officer is a referee, the decision of the judicial officer, or
in any other case, the decision of the referee appointed by the court to be senior referee.

If the court appoints 3 or more referees, any decision to be made in the course of proceedings under the reference may be made by a majority of the referees and, failing a majority, the decision that is binding is:
if a judicial officer is a referee, the decision of the judicial officer, or
in any other case, the decision of the referee appointed by the court to be senior referee.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.17] r 20.17 Inquiry and report (cf SCR Part 72, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Inquiry and report (cf SCR Part 72, rule 5)

p.text: The court may, at any time and from time to time:
authorise the referee to inquire into and report on any facts relevant to the inquiry and report on the matter referred, and
direct the referee to make a further or supplemental report or inquiry and report, and
give such instructions as the court thinks fit relating to the inquiry or report.
Instructions under subrule (1)(c) may include provision concerning any experiment or test for the purposes of any inquiry or report of a referee.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.18] r 20.18 Remuneration of referee (cf SCR Part 72, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Remuneration of referee (cf SCR Part 72, rule 6)

p.text: The court:
may determine the amount of the fees to be paid to a referee, and
may direct how, when and by whom the whole or any part of any such fees are to be payable, and
may determine the consequences of failure to comply with a direction under paragraph (b).
Subrule (1) does not affect the powers of the court as to costs.

An order appointing a referee should actually refer to the referee’s fees. Alternatively, the parties must enter into a firm agreement with the referee setting out the proposed fees. Otherwise when a claim is made to the court, ordinarily there must be evidence: (a) of the time actually spent by the referee; and (b) that the amount claimed is fair and reasonable: Buttrose v Versi (NSWSC, Young J, No 3568/90, 14 May 1992, unreported, BC9201877). If a referee wishes to claim a cancellation fee in the event that the time set aside for the reference is not required, that must be the subject of specific agreement between the parties. Ordinarily the court will not order the payment of such a fee: Amec Construction Pty Ltd v Coal and Allied Operations Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Cole J, 29 April 1993, unreported, BC9304215). A solicitor may be held jointly and severally liable with the client for a referee’s fees and the court should ensure that referees are paid proper fees for their work: Birkai Pty Ltd v Permanent Custodians Ltd (1994) 35 NSWLR 178; BC9405115 .

In the absence of actual bias, fraud or deliberate wrongdoing, referees enjoy a common law immunity from suit: Najjar v Haines (1991) 25 NSWLR 224 ; Buttrose v Versi (NSWSC, Young J, No 3568/90, 14 May 1992, unreported, BC9201877). Although a referee is immune from liability for damages for negligence, the referee’s fee may be abated for negligence: Buttrose v Versi , above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.19] r 20.19 Court rooms (cf SCR Part 72, rule 7)

p.text: The court may give directions for the provision:
of services of officers of the court, and
of court rooms and other facilities,
for the purpose of any reference under this Division.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.20] r 20.20 Conduct of proceedings under the reference (cf SCR Part 72, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Conduct of proceedings under the reference (cf SCR Part 72, rule 8)

p.text: The court may give directions with respect to the conduct of proceedings under the reference.
Subject to any direction under subrule (1):
the referee may conduct the proceedings under the reference in such manner as the referee thinks fit, and
in conducting proceedings under the reference, the referee is not bound by the rules of evidence but may inform himself or herself in relation to any matter in such manner as the referee thinks fit.
Evidence before the referee:
may be given orally or in writing, and
if the referee so requires, must, be given on oath or by affidavit.
A referee may take the examination of any person.

Each party must, within a time fixed by the referee but in any event before the conclusion of evidence on the inquiry, give to the referee and each other party a brief statement of the findings of fact and law for which the party contends.

The parties must at all times do all things which the referee requires to enable a just opinion to be reached and no party may wilfully do or cause to be done any act to delay or prevent an opinion being reached.

In appropriate cases, a referee may obtain assistance from others (such as partners and employees) in carrying out work necessary for the preparation of his report. Where matters are delegated to a referee’s staff, those matters must be within the competence of the staff and be subject to responsible supervision. However, all matters of substance should be dealt with by the referee personally: Telecomputing PCS Pty Ltd v Bridge Wholesale Acceptance Corp (Aust) Ltd (1991) 24 NSWLR 513 .
Legislation cited in [20.20.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 2010.

The judge will, when formulating directions, have regard to the provisions of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (NSW), the nature of the issues to be determined and the identity and qualifications of the referee. Where the referee is a technical expert, it is inappropriate to require that the rules of evidence be applied. The obligation to adhere to the rules of natural justice (see [20.20.20] ) does not mean that a technical expert appointed as a referee should observe formal judicial procedures: Beveridge v Dontan Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 13; 24 ALD 196 .
Legislation cited in [20.20.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 20.17(1)(c), 20.20(1).

The court may give instructions and directions to the referee pursuant to rr 20.17(1)(c) and 20.20(1) . The terms of those discretionary powers are wide and, notwithstanding the proposition that ordinarily a person is entitled to be legally represented (Chilton v Saga Holidays Plc [1986] 1 All ER 841 ; Pett v Greyhound Racing Assn Ltd [1969] 1 QB 125 at 132 ; R v Kelly; Ex parte Commonwealth Public Service Clerical Assn (1955) 92 CLR 10; [1955] ALR 385; BC5500550 ), the court may give directions excluding legal representatives from part of the proceedings before the referee: Triden Properties Ltd v Capita Financial Group Ltd (1993) 30 NSWLR 403 . It is doubtful, however, whether the width of the direction’s power could sustain a direction which purported to totally exclude the right of a party to legal representation in the proceedings before a referee. However, there is no principle of law that automatically guarantees a right to legal representation and it is possible that in particular cases the requirement of procedural fairness might be satisfied even though legal representation was excluded: Triden Properties Ltd v Capita Financial Group Ltd , above. It will be a breach of procedural fairness, however, where legal representation is excluded by the referee rather than the court: Argyle Lane Corp Pty Ltd v Tower Holdings Pty Ltd (1993) 10 BCL 273; BC9303886 .
Legislation cited in [20.20.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.20(2)(b).

The rule confers a wide scope for procedural flexibility in the conduct of the reference, but this is subject to the requirements of natural justice. The requirements of natural justice will vary according to the circumstances of each case. Referees must consider what is required to achieve fairness between the parties in the particular circumstances of their reference: see Xeureb v Viola (1989) 18 NSWLR 453 . Sometimes it may be appropriate for the referee to adopt procedures substantially the same as those that would apply to judicial proceedings: Clark Equipment Credit of Australia Ltd v Como Factors Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 552 (reference involving procedure similar to the taking of accounts). Generally, natural justice will require, in addition to the impartiality of the referee, that each party be afforded a proper opportunity to put its contentions, both in relation to matters raised by the opposing party and on any matters raised by the referee. Particularly is the latter requirement important where a referee has used the power in r 20.20(2)(b) to obtain information independently: Telecomputing PCS Pty Ltd v Bridge Wholesale Acceptance Corp (Aust) Ltd (1991) 24 NSWLR 513 . The referee should refrain from reaching a concluded opinion until each party has been afforded an opportunity to comment upon the information: Xuereb v Viola , above, at 470. On the other hand, natural justice is a matter of substance rather than form. Accordingly, where parties have been given a proper opportunity to put their respective cases in writing, the absence of an oral hearing and an opportunity to cross-examine a witness need not, depending upon the circumstances of the particular case, constitute a denial of natural justice: Beveridge v Dontan Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 13; 24 ALD 196 . A referee should not have private conversations with an expert, even to clarify aspects of the expert’s report: Xuereb v Viola , above, at 470. If there is such a private communication, the referee should inform the opposing party of the fact and of the information conveyed, to afford that party an appropriate opportunity to express views about it: Solah Blue Metal Pty Ltd v Tecma Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles J, 31 May 1991, unreported).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.21] r 20.21 Interlocutory directions (cf SCR Part 72, rule 9)

p.text: The court may, at any time and from time to time, on application of the referee or of a party, give directions with respect to any matter arising in proceedings under the reference.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.22] r 20.22 Setting aside or variation of reference (cf SCR Part 72, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Setting aside or variation of reference (cf SCR Part 72, rule 10)

p.text: The court may, of its own motion or on application by a referee or a party, set aside or vary any order of referral.
Nothing in this rule affects any other power of the court to set aside or vary an order of referral.

The ordinary principles about bias, both actual and apprehended, and the principles of natural justice, apply to referees. An order appointing a referee may be set aside where bias is established: Najjar v Haines (1991) 25 NSWLR 224 . The relevant test is whether an informed observer (S & M Motor Repairs Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1988) 12 NSWLR 358; 11 IPR 97; 91 FLR 175 ) who knows the actual circumstances of the case (Laws v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (1990) 170 CLR 70 at 87; 93 ALR 435; 64 ALJR 412; BC9002913 ) would regard the referee as subject to a reasonable risk of being unable to deal impartially with the proceedings: see [51.53.55]–[51.53.70] . A referee may be removed where their conduct of the reference has been such as to deny natural justice to a party and the denial cannot be cured by further directions from the court: Pimas Constructions Pty Ltd v Metropolitan Waste Disposal Authority (NSWSC, Brownie J, 4 August 1988, unreported, BC8801653): see [51.53.50] . Private communications between the referee and individual parties may indicate either bias or a denial of natural justice. However, such a conclusion depends on the context and content, rather than the mere fact, of the communication: Carbotech-Australia Pty Ltd v Yates [2008] NSWSC 540; BC200804077 (no reasonable apprehension of bias — communication between expert referee and plaintiff’s solicitors — attributable to unfamiliarity with reference protocol and procedure).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.23] r 20.23 Report (cf SCR Part 72, rules 11 and 12)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, the referee must make a written report to the court on the matter referred to the referee, annexing the statements given under rule 20.20(5) and stating:
the referee’s opinion on the matter, and
the referee’s reasons for that opinion.
On receipt of the report, the court must send it to the parties.
Legislation cited in [20.23.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.24.

While the giving of reasons is a normal incident of the judicial process, the extent of the duty is not always capable of precise definition: see [36.2.10] . That same difficulty applies to the obligations imposed by the present rule. What is required is a statement of reasons which will permit the court to properly exercise its own functions under r 20.24 . As a minimum, this would mean that the reasons ought to demonstrate sufficiently clearly the fundamental reasoning process that led to the conclusions set out in the report: Xeureb v Viola (1989) 18 NSWLR 453 ; Strbak v Newton (NSWSC, No 434/87, 18 July 1989, unreported, BC8901946); Najjar v Haines (1991) 25 NSWLR 224 . The obligation to provide reasons does not require that the referee has to make express findings upon every matter of fact and law that was contested in the proceedings: Housing Commission (NSW) v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378 at 385; (1983) 53 LGRA 325 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.24] r 20.24 Proceedings on the report (cf SCR Part 72, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings on the report (cf SCR Part 72, rule 13)

p.text: If a report is made under rule 20.23, the court may on a matter of fact or law, or both, do any of the following:
it may adopt, vary or reject the report in whole or in part,
it may require an explanation by way of report from the referee,
it may, on any ground, remit for further consideration by the referee the whole or any part of the matter referred for a further report,
it may decide any matter on the evidence taken before the referee, with or without additional evidence,
and must, in any event, give such judgment or make such order as the court thinks fit.
Evidence additional to the evidence taken before the referee may not be adduced before the court except by leave of the court.

level.toc-caption: [20.24.5] Adoption, variation or rejection of the report

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.24.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.24(1)(a)–(d).

heading.title: Adoption, variation or rejection of the report

p.text: It is apparent from the breadth of the powers contained in UCPR r 20.24(1)(a)–(d) , that the court has a wide discretion in relation to the adoption or rejection of referee’s reports. In deciding whether or not to adopt a referee’s report, the court will be concerned to satisfy itself that adoption is appropriate in all the circumstances. The extent of the investigation that the court will make in reaching the appropriate satisfaction will vary from case to case. The considerations relevant to the exercise of the discretion may include the nature of the proceedings, their length and complexity, the apparent competence and expertise of the referee, the procedures adopted by the referee and the nature of the evidence, as well as the nature, and apparent substance, of the complaints made about the report: Super Pty Ltd v SJP Formwork (Aust) Pty Ltd (1992) 29 NSWLR 549 ; Chloride Batteries Australia Ltd v Glendale Chemical Products Pty Ltd (1988) 17 NSWLR 60 at 67 ; Nicholls v Stamer [1980] VR 479 at 494 . Many cases discuss these considerations.

A useful summary of the relevant principles is set out in New South Wales v Bovis Lend Lease Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1045; BC200708058 at [6] and Chocolate Factory Apartments Pty Ltd v Westpoint Finance Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 784; BC200505723 at [6]–[8] — a passage that was referred to with approval in Bellvarde Construs Pty Ltd v CPC Energy Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 228; BC200808460 at [46]–[47] .

The discretion to reject or vary a referee’s report requires a “proper” justification — despite a suggestion that where the points in controversy may be shortly determined, the courts may have a greater willingness to embark upon a reconsideration of the referee’s report: Bermria Pty Ltd v Homebush Abattoir Corp (1991) 22 NSWLR 600 . It is inherent in the breadth of the discretion that neither party has any automatic right to have the reference proceedings reheard by the court: Super Pty Ltd v SJP Formwork (Aust) Pty Ltd (1992) 29 NSWLR 549 . The nature and purpose of the discretion is such that rejection of the report is not justified by a mere disagreement with the referee’s factual findings or the inferences drawn from those findings: Ryde City Council v Tourtouras [2007] NSWCA 218; BC200706892 at [23] .

The circumstances in which a court may reject a report include where the referee has made a significant error of principle — including, but not confined to, an error of law: Ryde City Council v Tourtouras [2007] NSWCA 218; BC200706892 at [23] . Specific examples are situations where the referee:
acted perversely or unreasonably;
acted outside the scope of the matters referred;
misapprehended the evidence;

see Super Pty Ltd v SJP Formwork (Aust) Pty Ltd, above; Walter Construction Group Ltd v Walker Corp Ltd (2001) 47 ATR 48; [2001] NSWSC 283; BC200102189 ; Chloride Batteries Australia Ltd v Glendale Chemical Products Pty Ltd, above; State Authorities Superannuation Board v Property Estates (Qld) Pty Ltd (1991) 11 BCL 28; BC9102378 ; Falgat Constructions Pty Ltd v Lightning Ready Mixed Concrete Pty Ltd (NSWCA), 25 November 1994, unreported, BC9403305); Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd v Federal Airports Corp (1997) 47 NSWLR 631; BC9705145 .
In assessing a report to determine whether it merits any of these pejorative descriptions a court will consider factors such as:

whether the parties had a proper opportunity to address all of the matters found by the referee: Eko Investments Pty Ltd v Austruc Constructions Ltd [2009] NSWSC 208; BC200902006 (referee’s finding outside the pleaded case);

whether the report demonstrates a thorough, analytical and scientific approach by the referee: Chloride Batteries Australia Ltd v Glendale Chemical Products Pty Ltd, above at 67 ; Bermria Pty Ltd v Homebush Abattoir Corp (1991) 22 NSWLR 600 ; Foxman Holdings Pty Ltd v NMBE Pty Ltd (1994) 38 NSWLR 615; BC9402612 ;

whether the referee’s report is perverse or manifestly unreasonable to the extent that no reasonable tribunal of fact could have made the decision: Foxman Holdings Pty Ltd v NMBE Pty Ltd (1994) 38 NSWLR 615 at 620; BC9402612 .

Even when relevant error has been demonstrated the court may still, as UCPR r 20.24(1)(a) indicates, adopt or vary a referee’s answers to the questions referred without adopting the reasons given by the referee: Astor Properties Pty Ltd v L'Union des Assurance de Paris (1989) 17 NSWLR 483 .

level.toc-caption: [20.24.10] Appeal from adoption or rejection of report

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.24.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 20.13–20.24, r 20.24.

heading.title: Appeal from adoption or rejection of report

p.text: The procedure for reference, report and adoption, variation or rejection under UCPR rr 20.13–20.24 provides a form of dispute resolution that is alternative to orthodox litigation. The principles that govern the court’s functions under UCPR r 20.24 in relation to adoption of a referee’s report, the procedure does not involve an extra level of appeal in the ordinary litigious process: Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd v CE Heath Underwriting & Agency Services (1995) 8 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-231; (1994) 12 BCL 415; BC9402998 . An appeal lies only from a judge’s adoption, variation or rejection of a referee’s report. The function of the appellate court is to determine whether the judge was in error in relation to the adoption, variation or rejection (Abigroup Contractors Pty Ltd v Sydney Catchment Authority (2004) 208 ALR 630; [2004] NSWCA 270; BC200404975 at [16] ) nor is the appeal. Relevant error will exist if the judge has made an error of law, has acted on a wrong view of the discretion to adopt or reject the report, or has made an error of fact in the judge’s own consideration of the evidence; Flender (Aust) Pty Ltd v Warman International Ltd (NSWCA, Handley, Beazley JJA and Sheppard AJA, 18 June 1998, unreported, BC9802458); Ryde City Council v Tourtouras [2007] NSWCA 218; BC200706892 at [36], [42] (judge’s misapprehension of the scope of discretion — appeal allowed).

Consistent with those principles an appeal from a reference adoption decision is not directly concerned with the nature and extent of any errors made by the referee: Nine Network Pty Ltd v Kennedy Miller Television Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Gleeson CJ, Meagher and Handley JJA, No 40641/93, 8 June 1994, unreported, BC9405038); Super Pty Ltd v SJP Formwork (Aust) Pty Ltd, above; Flender (Aust) Pty Ltd v Warman International Ltd (NSWCA, Handley, Beazley JJA and Sheppard AJA, CA 40342/95, 18 June 1998, unreported, BC9802458); Jarvan Pty Ltd (in liq) v Seery (NSWCA, Meagher, Sheller and Stein JJA 1 December 1998, unreported, BC9806365). If the ground of appeal is that the judge either misunderstood, or repeated, the referee’s error, then the referee’s error may be indirectly relevant — as a necessary means of identifying the error in the judge’s reasoning: Westpoint Management Ltd v Chocolate Factory Apartments Ltd [2007] NSWCA 253; BC200708069 (referred and “adopting” judge acted on a wrong principle in the assessment of damages for breach of contract). Conversely, a referee’s error that was not relied on in opposition to the judge’s adoption decision is not even indirectly relevant to the appeal issues: Bellevarde Constructions Pty Ltd v CPC Energy Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 228; BC200808460 at [51]–[60] (complaint about lack of evidence to justify assessment of damages).

level.toc-caption: [20.24.15] Evidence of the proceedings before the referee

p.text: Legislation cited in [20.24.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.24(1)(d).

heading.title: Evidence of the proceedings before the referee

p.text: Despite the terms of r 20.24(1)(d) , the evidence, if any, tendered before a referee is not evidence in the proceedings. It may become evidence in the proceedings only if it is tendered and admitted into evidence in the usual way: Homebush Abattoir Corp v Bermria Pty Ltd (1991) 22 NSWLR 605 at 608 . Ordinarily the court will be able to determine the application without revisiting the detailed evidence to support the findings of fact made by the referee (Skinner & Edwards (Builders) Pty Ltd v Australian Telecommunications Corp (1992) 27 NSWLR 567 ; Foxman Holdings Pty Ltd v NMBE Pty Ltd (1994) 38 NSWLR 615 at 620; BC9402612 ), and when such evidence is tendered, the judge is not obliged nor required to read and review the entirety of the evidence: Lee Gleeson Pty Ltd v Sterling Estates Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 571 at 588 .

The court is not obliged to reconsider weight of evidence submissions, or to review evidence and submissions on factual questions. However, the report must sufficiently state the referee's reasons for critical findings of fact: Sydney Water Corp Ltd v Aqua Clear Technology Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rolfe J, No 55047/96, 17 December 1996, unreported, BC9606091). The court may reconsider a question of fact if it is not comfortably satisfied that the reasons disclosed in the report reasonably support the findings made by the referee: Skinner & Edwards (Builders) Pty Ltd v Australian Telecommunications Corp (1992) 27 NSWLR 567 . Where a party seeks to oppose the adoption of a report on the basis of an attack on the referee’s finding that he preferred the evidence of one witness rather than another, a referee is in the same position and enjoys the same advantages as a trial judge and the doctrine in Abalos v Australian Postal Commission (1990) 171 CLR 167; 96 ALR 354 is equally applicable: Shellcove Developments Pty Ltd v Constantine (1994) 10 BCL 333. It is not a basis for the rejection of the referee’s report that the referee has not articulated his reasons for preferring the evidence of one witness to another: ECC Lighting Ltd v McGurk (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 9 February 1996, unreported, BC9600160). It follows that a report may be adopted or acted upon even if the judge might, on his own consideration of the evidence, have reached a conclusion different from that of the referee: Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd v CE Heath Underwriting & Agency Services (1995) 8 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-231; (1994) 12 BCL 415 . On the other hand, where the reference involves technical matters or a long complicated hearing, the court will be disinclined to reject the report unless it is shown to have been erroneous: Mackintosh v Great Western Railway Co (1865) 66 ER 881 ; Najjar v Haines (1991) 25 NSWLR 224 ; Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 . It will also be disinclined to permit a party to seek to demonstrate error in the report by relying upon additional evidence that ought to have been put before the referee: Nicholls v Stamer [1980] VR 479 at 494 ; Attorney-General v Birmingham Tame and Rea District Drainage Board [1912] AC 788 at 811 .

The circumstances in which the court might exercise the power to remit are not specified in the rules. In King v Thomas McKenna Ltd [1991] 1 All ER 653 at 680 , Lord Donaldson MR dealt with the power to remit a matter to an arbitrator pursuant to s 22 of the Arbitration Act 1950 (UK). The Master of the Rolls described the power as exercisable whenever the subject matter of the proceedings had not been adjudicated upon “as fully as, or in a manner which, the parties were entitled to expect”, and that as a result “it would be inequitable to allow any award to take effect”. His Lordship referred to four traditional grounds upon which the power had been exercised:
where the award was bad on its face;
where the arbitrator had been guilty of misconduct;
where there was an admitted mistake by the arbitrator and there had been a request for remittal;
where additional evidence had been discovered after the making of the award.

Consistent with this general approach, a failure to afford natural justice to the parties may lead to an order to remit the proceedings to the referee for further consideration: Flender (Aust) Pty Ltd v Warman International Ltd (NSWCA, CA 40342/95, 18 June 1998, unreported, BC9802458); Rhodes v Fletcher [2000] NSWSC 797; BC200004980 ; Telecomputing PCS Pty Ltd v Bridge Wholesale Acceptance Corp (Aust) Ltd (1991) 24 NSWLR 513 at 523 . In addition, inadequate reasoning may provide a basis for remitting the report: Powers v Stoikos [2007] NSWSC 675; BC200705054 (mortgage calculations requiring further explanation).

But there will be situations where the deficiency in the proceedings before, or the contents of the report by, the referee makes remission of the proceedings undesirable: Alamdo Holdings Pty Ltd v Australian Window Furnishings (NSW) Pty Ltd [2004] ANZ ConvR 351; [2004] NSWSC 487; BC200403296 (gross delay by referee and failure to deal with relevant issues); Forrest v Appleyard [2007] NSWSC 889; BC200706439 (errors of principle, likelihood of significant delay and additional cost — leave granted to adduce further evidence — report varied).

Where the points in issue relate principally to questions of law, the court is both entitled and bound to decide for itself whether the report is correct: Super Pty Ltd v SJP Formwork (Aust) Pty Ltd , above; Homebush Abattoir Corp v Bermria Pty Ltd (1991) 22 NSWLR 605 ; Maritime Services Board of New South Wales v Australian Shipping Commission (1991) 27 NSWLR 258 .

level.toc-caption: [20.24.35] Point of law not raised before the referee

heading.title: Point of law not raised before the referee

p.text: The question whether a point of law not taken before a referee should be allowed to be argued before the court should be considered as part of the court’s general discretion to adopt or reject the report. In the exercise of that discretion, it is not necessarily appropriate for the court to adopt the same approach that would be taken on an appeal where a party seeks to rely upon a point of law that was not taken in the court below: Australian Development Corp Pty Ltd v White Constructions (ACT) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles J, No 55041/91, 14 October 1993, unreported, BC9302150).
